entry.title: SAP’s New Logistics Management Module: A Cloud-Native Approach to Smarter Regional Supply Chains
entry.content:
At SAP Connect 2025 in Los Angeles, SAP unveiled a number of innovations in the supply chain space and one of the most notable is SAP Logistics Management, a new cloud-native solution designed to streamline and unify logistics operations  across warehouses, transportation, and logistics partners.

This launch reflects SAP’s strategy to simplify logistics for distributed and regional operations while enabling real-time visibility, automation, and collaboration across the supply chain network.

In this blog post, I will take you through what the module is, what its capabilities are, how it fits into the SAP ecosystem, and what it means for companies looking to modernise their logistics operations and all within one intelligent cloud platform.

Read the full blog to explore features, business impact, and practical steps to prepare your logistics operations for the next generation of SAP innovation.

What Is SAP Logistics Management?

SAP Logistics Management is a modern SaaS-based logistics solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It brings together warehousing, transportation management, and partner collaboration in a single, integrated system — particularly suited for regional or satellite operations  while connecting seamlessly with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Key Attributes

  • Cloud-native: Designed for seamless scalability, continuous innovation, and rapid deployment.
  • Unified logistics approach: Combines warehouse, transport execution, orchestration, and partner collaboration into one platform.
  • Native ERP integration: Connects easily with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP S/4HANA without heavy customisation.
  • Carrier & partner collaboration: Built-in connectivity through the SAP Business Network for real-time visibility and data sharing.
  • AI-powered operations (Joule): Leverages SAP Joule AI assistants to automate tasks, guide decisions, and reduce manual workload.

In short, SAP Logistics Management doesn’t replace heavy-duty logistics systems like SAP EWM or SAP TM, but rather extends SAP’s portfolio with a lighter, agile, intelligent logistics layer ideal for regional warehouses and distributed networks.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image Source: SAP Product Information Page (sap.com)

Positioning Within the SAP Ecosystem

SAP positions this module as a bridge for distributed logistics operations, extending logistics capabilities to smaller or regional nodes. It complements, not replaces the SAP Extended Warehouse Management and SAP Transportation Management .

Because it’s built on SAP BTP and integrates with SAP Business Network and Joule AI, the new module aligns with SAP’s vision of an intelligent, integrated supply chain.
SAP announced that general availability is expected in Q1 2026.

Benefits & Business Value

Adopting SAP Logistics Management can deliver both operational and strategic gains:

  1. Reduced operational friction: Unified logistics reduces manual handoffs and integration gaps.
  2. Faster deployment for regional nodes: Cloud-native architecture enables quicker rollouts and lower implementation costs.
  3. Improved visibility & collaboration: Real-time tracking and partner integration enhance transparency and agility.
  4. AI-driven decision support: Joule AI assists planners, automates routine actions, and reduces human error.
  5. Scalable, modular growth: Deploy gradually across logistics nodes without disrupting existing core systems.
  6. Resilient and agile operations: Respond faster to disruptions and maintain consistent service levels.
  7. Network consistency: Standardised processes and data across multiple logistics layers ensure global alignment.

Key Challenges & Considerations

While promising, success depends on thoughtful execution.
Organisations should anticipate and plan for:

  • Scope & complexity limits: The module is optimised for low-to-medium complexity; large hubs may still need EWM + TM.
  • Data integration & master data quality: Consistent, clean master data is critical for seamless performance.
  • Change management: AI-driven workflows require user adoption and training.
  • Phased rollout strategy: Identify pilot nodes and migration paths carefully.
  • Carrier & partner readiness: True collaboration depends on network adoption.
  • Monitoring & exception handling: Maintain human oversight during early automation phases.
  • Cost vs. ROI alignment: Evaluate expected efficiency gains against investment costs.

 

What Businesses Should Do Next

If your organization already runs SAP Cloud ERP or S/4HANA, this launch presents a real opportunity to modernise logistics without starting from scratch.

Recommended Next Steps

  • Map your logistics footprint: Identify which regional or satellite nodes would benefit most.
  • Start with pilot deployments: Test configurations, training, and ROI in smaller sites.
  • Ensure data readiness: Clean up and harmonize master data across materials, locations, and partners.
  • Engage carriers early: Align carriers and logistics partners with the collaboration network from the start.
  • Plan coexistence: Integrate with existing EWM/TM during the transition phase.
  • Adopt AI in stages: Roll out automation features gradually and monitor outcomes.
  • Track KPIs from day one: Measure order throughput, dock utilisation, exception rates, and on-time delivery.

Conclusion 

The introduction of SAP Logistics Management marks a pivotal step in SAP’s supply chain evolution - moving toward networked, intelligent, and modular logistics.

With its cloud-native architecture, AI-powered automation, and embedded collaboration, it offers a compelling value proposition for companies with multi-tier logistics footprints.

Ultimately, success will depend on data readiness, partner engagement, and phased adoption but for organisations ready to embrace intelligent logistics, SAP is clearly paving the way for smarter, more connected supply chains.

Thank you for reading.

entry.title: Managing Change When Adopting AI
entry.content:
Adopting AI

The benefits of AI in supply chain management are evident, but implementing it might not be as clear.
Change management is an important aspect of any implementation which needs to be taken into consideration and made a priority ahead of any roll-out. Change management needs to be a high priority to ensure adoption. 
 
Conversational Planning

 In this blog, I'll explore the following topics

  • Change Management
  • How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Change Management

Change management always starts with clear communication about the value of the upcoming change and crafting a plan that involves user input. AI in the supply chain will improve human experiences by automating repetitive tasks, enabling employees to learn new skills that will benefit both the business and their personal growth. With the conversational planning use case in SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management, a user can now reduce their planning time by at least 50% with the help of AI. This use case compliments the user's domain knowledge with AI driven data and real-time information. e.g. Plan all products that need to be transported to Orlando on a semi-truck with a 53' trailer. A user will interact through natural language. 

How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Once a use case is setup in the test environment, users need to be trained on the new process to ensure better success. This is a link to the initial setup. SAP note 3573759 has more information of setting up conversational planning in SAP TM. The testing phase needs to be thorough with real-life data. These kinds of changes will probably require a pilot phase and can be rolled out once the value has been proven, these employees are likely to become your AI ambassadors fuelling excitement into the new technology which is always the best motivation for change ! Once the business is excited for these new improvements, these processes can be embedded in to the business. 
 
Route Planning with AI
 

This blog was an overview of what can be expected when implementing AI use cases in supply chain management and how to deal with change management.

In my next blog I plan to cover another AI use case in SAP Transportation Management, AI assisted good receipt analysis.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era — Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview — Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Key Design Principles

Principle Description
Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.
AI-enabledEmbedded Joule AI assistant supports planning and exception handling.
Network-readyPre-integrated with SAP Business Network for Logistics.
Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope — From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics — Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics — all running in the cloud.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit

InboundGoods receipt, putaway, inspectionReduce manual errors and waiting time.
InternalBin management, replenishmentOptimize space and movement.
OutboundPicking, packing, staging, loadingFaster fulfillment accuracy.
MobileScanning & task confirmationReal-time execution; paperless workflow.
MonitoringDashboards & alertsImprove supervisory visibility.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer’s regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels — no need for spreadsheets.

Key Fiori Apps in Warehouse Logistics

App Name Usage
Warehouse MonitorSupervisors track workload, resources, exceptions.
Execute Warehouse TasksOperators perform putaway/picking with handhelds.
Manage Inbound DeliveriesCreate, monitor, and post receipts for inbound deliveries.

Transportation Logistics — Intelligent Freight Orchestration

Transportation Logistics in LGM brings planning, tendering, execution, and freight costing into one intelligent workflow. It eliminates spreadsheet-based planning and manual RFQs by integrating real-time carrier collaboration.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
PlanningLoad building, route optimisation & consolidationCut freight costs and carbon footprint.
TenderingPeer-to-peer / broadcast to carriersAutomate carrier selection.
ExecutionFreight order tracking & event managementAchieve end-to-end visibility.
CostingFreight cost calculation & invoice reconciliationImprove financial accuracy.
AppointmentDock scheduling & time windowsReduce waiting time and idle assets.

Manage Freight RFQs App: A chemical manufacturer planning an urgent dispatch to Delhi creates an RFQ in LGM. Three carriers receive tenders instantly via BN4L; within minutes, Carrier A accepts with best price and lead time — no emails or phone calls needed.

Key Fiori Apps in Transportation Logistics

App Name Usage
Manage Freight RFQsCreate/manage carrier RFQs.
Tender Freight OrdersPublish freight offers to carriers.
Track Freight OrdersView live shipment events & status.

Network Collaboration — Connected by Design

Network Collaboration within SAP LGM links shippers and carriers digitally via the SAP Business Network for Logistics. It replaces emails and calls with structured collaboration — carrier tenders, dock appointments, shipment events, and POD uploads all happen in one network workspace.

Category Capabilities Business Benefit
Carrier CollaborationTender acceptance / status updatesFaster onboarding, less manual follow-up.
Appointment SchedulingDock slot managementSmoother inbound/outbound flow.
Tracking & EventsMilestones & delay alertsPredictive visibility.
DocumentationProof of Delivery / Freight invoice sharingPaperless compliance.

Manage Carrier Collaboration App: A transport partner accepts a freight order from the shipper and uploads the signed POD once delivery is complete. The system automatically updates LGM and triggers freight invoice posting in ERP.

Key Fiori Apps in Network Collaboration

App Name Usage
Manage Carrier CollaborationDigital tender acceptance & status updates.
Schedule Dock AppointmentsDock slot coordination with carriers.
Monitor Shipment MilestonesTrack shipment events and POD status.

Unified Planning & Control — Visibility in One View

Narrative
The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

Feature Description
Unified Planning ConsoleAggregate view of all logistics plans & statuses.
Control TowerMonitors execution progress and exceptions.
KPI DashboardsVisualises service levels and throughput.
Exception HandlingGuided workflows to resolve delays and errors.

Logistics Dashboard App: A distribution manager opens the dashboard each morning to view all facilities on one screen. If a lane’s OTD drops below 95 %, he drills into that carrier and sends an RFQ for replacement service — action taken within minutes, not days.

Key Fiori Apps in Unified Planning & Control

App Name Usage
Logistics DashboardKPI overview of logistics network.
Exception Management HubCentralised issue tracking & resolution.
Dashboard for PlanningCompare planned vs actual performance.

Integration — Seamless by Default

LGM connects to SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network using standard APIs and content packages. Data flows bi-directionally for deliveries, goods movements, freight costs and invoices. This ensures a single source of truth across finance and operations.

Intelligence Layer — Joule AI for Smarter Decisions

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is built into LGM. It understands context, answers in natural language, and automates common decisions like carrier selection or route replanning.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

A planner types, “Which deliveries are at risk today?” Joule returns a list of orders facing delays and suggests rescheduling or alternate carriers based on historic performance. The planner approves in one click — no manual analysis

Business Benefits — Tangible Value for Growing Companies

VisibilityUnified planning console gives end-to-end control.
EfficiencyAI and automation reduce manual coordination effort.
ScalabilityStart with one site or process, expand as needed.

entry.title: Data quality comes at a price - also in in hospitals and clinics
entry.content:
Source: generated by Google Gemini

Initial situation

Data quality plays an essential role in virtually all core processes in hospitals and clinics, whether in medication, patient care, or supply logistics. In addition, data quality is not only an operational necessity, but also vital to compliance with regulations and laws (e.g., traceability of drugs or implants).

“Garbage in = garbage out”

This makes it all the more important for every hospital or clinic to be aware of the importance of efficient data management.

In reality, however, there are many challenges in this area because the historically grown and often very heterogeneous system landscape with numerous clinical systems, ERP systems, and additional applications makes centralized and uniform data management difficult. In terms of data quality, it should be added that master data in particular must be maintained and distributed with a great deal of effort, often manually, which leads to the undesirable situation of poor-quality master data entering the clinical systems (“garbage in”) and the resulting transaction data in the form of prescriptions, services, or consumption (“garbage out”) being transferred from the systems to the ERP system.

This leads to numerous operational problems, whether in the supply logistics of medicines, medical products, and consumables for patients, suboptimal procurement of these operationally essential goods, or ultimately in rejections by health insurance companies due to incorrect service invoices.

Way out

Anyone who believes that the use of new technologies or new tools such as AI will solve the problems described above is likely to be bitterly disappointed. Instead, what is needed is the establishment of a centrally managed and organizationally strong data management system with the aim of creating a new awareness of a “data-centric” orientation within the organization.

What are the most important factors for successful data management to ensure data quality?

  1. Golden source: The principle is one “golden source” per data area or data object. Ideally, there is only one system (e.g., data warehouse, master data management) in the target architecture as the leading system or “golden source.” In practice, however, this is not always feasible due to the system landscape and its history and complexity, because the implementation does not justify the expected benefits due to the anticipated costs and implementation time. It is therefore much more important to mandatorily always define one leading system or one “golden source” per data area or data object.
  2. Validation: Data quality can be ensured most easily and efficiently at the source or during data generation. With suitable validation rules, necessary technical (e.g., pharmaceutical validation of drugs) and technical (e.g., duplicate checking) rules can be checked. This is the only way to prevent “bad” data from entering the system in the first place.
  3. Automation: Unfortunately, manual data entry or data mutations of any kind are a frequent cause of operational inefficiencies, loss of data quality, and, last but not least, great frustration for data users. The maxim is therefore: as little manual intervention as possible in data transfer or data distribution, but maximum data automation via suitable interfaces, including monitoring and, if necessary, error messages (alerting).
  4. Quality assurance: In practice, actual quality assurance is often neglected because employees are often busy with manual or semi-automated data tasks and do not have the time for quality assurance. First, the data management challenges described above must be solved so that, in the next stage of data maturity, quality assurance with corresponding quality reports or KPIs can be achieved. However, once these control mechanisms for data quality have been implemented, quality problems can be identified much earlier (e.g., data records with missing batch information for implants) and more proactively (e.g., incorrect data records in service billing), and appropriate measures can be taken. Added to this are the possibilities offered by AI to apply increasingly intelligent control mechanisms.

Source: own illustration

Conclusion

Data quality is not a “sure-fire success” and comes at a price. However, this is less about implementing new IT systems and IT tools and more about organizational awareness of the importance of professional data management. Otherwise, the old adage “garbage in = garbage out” will remain true, resulting in costly operational inefficiency and a lack of potential for more digitized and data-driven processes.

entry.title: Supply Chain Planning Reimagined: Charting the Path to Decision-Centric, Autonomous Planning
entry.content:
For decades, supply chain leaders have been on a relentless quest for greater efficiency. We've built global networks, mastered lean inventory, and embraced automation at breakneck speeds. But the last few years have upended comfortable certainties. Geopolitical upheaval, pandemic ripple effects, and climate-related disruptions have rewritten the rules—turning volatility into the new normal. Today, planning is no longer a periodic exercise; it’s a dynamic, always-on process at the heart of business resilience and agility.

To empower confident and resilient planning companies need to synchronize decision-making across end-to-end supply chains, and drive sustainable value through data science, AI-powered insights, and transformative, outcomes-centric processes.

The Challenge: Confronting Complexity and Persistent Change

Supply chain leaders face an environment defined by persistent uncertainty. Plans must change not by quarter or by month—but sometimes by hour. Yet too many organizations are still hampered by legacy silos and fragmented tools, resulting in disjointed planning, slow decision cycles, and out-of-date data. The pressure to keep peace and indeed to anticipate disruption has never been greater.

The journey from data to action is often bogged down in manual handoffs, conflicting KPIs, and limited scenario planning, limiting the impact of even the best talent and intentions.

The Vision: Decision-Centric, Autonomous Planning

The future belongs to forward-thinking leaders who embrace a new model: decision-centric, autonomous supply chain planning.

But what does this mean in practice?

  • Integrated Decision-Centric Planning to achieve resilient and optimized mid to long-range plans with an AI-powered planning platform. This enables companies to seamlessly collaborate across supply chain, commercial, and finance teams to deliver financially smart scenario plans and adapt to market shifts with confidence.
  • Autonomous Planning and Decision Making by accelerating operational agility across the business network to enhance decision-making across the entire supply chain.
  • Post Planning Decision Intelligence and Actioning to enable cross-functional planning and real-time decisions by tracking plan-to-execution against KPIs, and enabling continuous corrective actions for enhanced agility across your value chain.
  • Convergence of supply chain silos by Integrating real-time data, synchronizing production and scheduling, and collaborating across the network to enhance agility, optimize resources, and improve customer satisfaction.
  • Unified Planner Experience through streamlined planning views for supply chain leaders and decision makers.
  • Put people at the Center to enable a human-centric supply chain that transforms your operations by autonomously executing routine tasks to free up people to focus on high-value activities.

By connecting these capabilities, companies can create a unified workspace designed with planners in mind to anticipating risk, managing by exception, and relentlessly driving better outcomes.

Delivering Tangible Value: The Autonomous Advantage

What does this look like in measurable business impact?

SAP’s advanced planning platform is driving real results for companies worldwide:

  • Up to 24% improved forecast accuracy and up to 82% lower revenue loss due to stockouts by unifying data and automating demand sensing.
  • 4–20% improvement in on-time, in-full delivery, boosting customer satisfaction and loyalty.
  • Optimized working capital through smarter inventory placement and risk-aware scenario planning.
  • Faster planning cycles so that teams that once updated plans weekly can now adapt in near real-time, reallocating resources in minutes rather than days.
  • Actionable alerts and “guided” user experiences allowing supply chain teams to focus on the deviations that matter, rather than drowning in data noise.

Critically, this approach enables organizations not just to react faster, but to leap ahead, and to turn their supply chain from a cost center into a competitive differentiator.

Cultivating a Culture of Continuous Improvement

Adopting decision-centric, autonomous planning is more than a technology upgrade. It requires a fundamental shift in mindset: from reactive firefighting to proactive, empowered problem-solving.

The most successful teams are those that embrace change, foster collaboration, and encourage learning at every level.

At SAP, we strive to be a trusted partner on this journey, providing not just technology, but proven business templates, industry best practices, and a collaborative ecosystem. Our mission is to help planners and decision-makers become architects of resilience and agents of innovation in their organizations.

Charting the Path Forward

In today’s landscape, the only constant is change, and the urgency for more agile, intelligent supply chains is undeniable. The winners of tomorrow will be those who act today to unlock new levels of confidence, speed, and value creation through decision-centric, autonomous planning.

Whether you’re a seasoned supply chain executive or rising operations leader, now is the time to ask:

  • Are your planning processes set up not just for efficiency, but for resilience and continuous transformation?
  • Are your teams empowered to make decisions at the speed of business—or held back by legacy limitations?

At SAP, our promise is to help you reimagine what supply chain planning can achieve: empowering your talent, unleashing innovation, and turning complexity into your greatest advantage.

To learn more, listen to a recent Future of Supply Chain podcast with SAP Supply Chain Planning, Chief Product Officer SP van Houten - Episode 131: Supply Chain Planning Re-imagined with SAP’s SP van Houten

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes it’s not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Let’s look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection don’t have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see  How to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in the Review Availability Check Result app, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see  Supply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand can’t get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC can’t get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isn’t exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity can’t get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesn’t have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and there’s also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer can’t order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isn’t possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection – Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, it’s possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldn’t make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be “losers”, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there won’t be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesn’t have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 
  • SAP Help: Temporary Assignment in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP 
  • Learning: Exploring aATP in SAP S/4HANA

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 1 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Future Supply Chain Management Works

More and more companies have recognized the critical power of supply chain management for business success – without viable supply chains, there are no satisfied customers, no successful product launches, and no stable value creation. Supply chains need to continuously evolve to meet these needs. Today, digital technologies open up numerous opportunities, which you could only dream of a few years ago: more accurate forecasts, fully connected partner networks, and near-autonomous operations.

At the same time, the economic environment is changing at a rapid pace: geopolitical tensions, changing customer needs, and climate change pose additional challenges for companies. In ten years’ time, supply chain management will look different than today – more connected, data-driven, and more adaptable than ever before. But what exactly will change, and how can companies prepare for it today? To answer these questions, SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University conducted a comprehensive study last year, the results of which we present in today’s and the next five issues.

We are building on a previous study in which we analyzed the visions of the future of companies in the middle of the “Digital SC Hypes” ten years ago. The mood was euphoric: From numerous conversations with supply chain managers, over 120 potential use cases arose – from 3D printed Lego stones to the use of social media data in sales forecasting to mini factories, ultra-fast BOM resolution, and last mile drone delivery. Companies were ready to invest and experiment with new technologies. Much was visionary, some sounded like science fiction – and yet the digital revolution in supply chains seemed tangibly close.

Our follow-up study shows a significantly changed picture. Pragmatic realism has given way to the great euphoria. Over the last 10 years, many technologies have been introduced slower and to a lesser extent than expected. The reasons for this include underestimated complexity and misconceptions about the performance of digital solutions (e.g. augmented reality, 3D printing or IoT), as well as an often inadequate technological state of development in the companies. Often, immature technologies, talent shortages, and inconsistent data quality slowed down execution.

Of course, there were also some pioneers – often from industries with high pressure to innovate – who secure an advantage with targeted investments and know-how. Success often correlated with a focus on clearly outlined use cases with rapid return on investment: better delivery reliability, fewer disruptions, quickly tangible value for the user.

This has been further reinforced by the recent years of pandemic, geopolitical tensions and economic weaknesses. Digital solutions for increasing automation, building integrated planning platforms, or tools to improve the customer experience are now only introduced if their value is clearly demonstrated. Successful projects usually start small and are not scaled until they have a proven effect. Lack of data quality, talent shortages, and lack of system integration are some of the biggest hurdles. Consistent data and change management is indispensable.

Between 2015 and 2025, the view of digital technologies has changed significantly: away from technology-driven euphoria, towards a use-oriented deployment. The potential to achieve true competitive advantage with new technologies in supply chain management is enormous. However, many companies are still lagging behind technology leaders today.

As part of our study, several surveys were conducted with a total of approximately 660 supply chain experts to understand today’s situation and expectations for 2035. In a multitude of in-depth discussions on Plan, Source, Make, Deliver, and People, we identified measures that companies should implement immediately, regardless of the scenario.

There are some exciting insights for the 2035 supply chains. First, the foundation of any successful digital transformation is a significant improvement in data quality. Companies also need appropriate tools to leverage this data and not remain “data-rich but insights poor.” People will continue to be important in the future, but their roles are changing. When AI takes on most of the operational work, and employees primarily monitor and develop, they are responsible for tasks that they have never practically performed themselves. Value chain silos will disappear, and technology-driven planning enables seamless end-to-end control.

Few innovation leaders like Amazon, Apple or Procter & Gamble will be able to set new standards on their own. Most organizations do not have comparable budgets, skills, or talents. They will make technological leaps, especially if they can use market-based standard solutions and thus participate in developments.

Regardless of the individual level of maturity, it is possible to record: If you want to play at the front in 2035, you must already start implementing “no-regret moves”: for example, establish robust data governance, standardize processes, and introduce employees specifically to AI tools. Companies that lay these foundations today will not only use technologies in 2035, but will use them strategically. Or, to say it with the words of Wayne Gretzky, “Good players skate to the puck. Great players skate to where the puck is going to be.“

In the second part of the series, we will show in the next issue why supply chain planning is becoming the decisive success factor, what gaps exist here today between ambition and reality, and how companies can prepare for 2035 with data, AI, and agents. In the subsequent expenditures, we will examine the key findings of our research in the areas of purchasing, production, distribution, and employees.

 

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) and Florian Diehlmann (SAP) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future”.

entry.title: Extensibility in Supply Protection
entry.content:
Supply protection operates on some fundamental principles. A demand can match a time bucket, but it can't match different buckets within one protection group. Another core principle is that a matching demand only consumes the protection of the time bucket it matches. If there's no remaining protection for this bucket, the consumption is still recorded for this time bucket. In this case, the remaining protection is zero, not negative. 

Sometimes, customers prefer more flexibility. 

An alternative could be to shift consumption to a time bucket with remaining protection. If the protection of a time bucket is fully consumed, a matching demand should first consume protection of the previous or next time bucket instead of exceeding the protection of the current bucket. 

Another, more specific alternative could be a change for the privileged check quantity if supply protection is set to Restriction outside planned protection. With this setting, a demand has low restriction if protection is remaining for the matching time bucket. If there is no protection remaining, the restriction is quite high.  

Some customers like to be even more flexible. For example, they might want to use the quantity from the next time bucket, the aggregation of all time buckets in the group, or just a defined quantity as the privileged check quantity, instead of the quantity of a single time bucket.  

All these use cases are supported with the help of the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs). 

  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Redistribution of Consumption (OP 2023 FPS0) 
    (ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection – Removal of Restriction Groups (OP2023 FPS0) 
    (ATP_SUP_REMOVAL_RSTRCN_GROUPS) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Remove Restriction Groups Inside Privileged Check Quantity (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Remove Restriction Groups Outside Privileged Check Quantity (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_OUT) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Change of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT) 

Let’s take a look at the options the different BAdIs provide: 

Redistribution of Consumption (ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN) 

By default, the consumption of protection is assigned only to the matching time bucket and reduces the remaining protection. With the help of the BAdI to redistribute the consumption, it is also possible to write consumptions in other time buckets of the matching protection group. 

One use case is to only write consumptions in the matching time bucket if there is still a remaining protection. If all the protection is consumed, the next consumption should be assigned to another time bucket like the previous or the next time bucket. 


Illustration: Matching Sales Order


Illustration: Distribution of protection across different time buckets with BAdI ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN 

Removal of Restriction Groups (ATP_SUP_REMOVAL_RSTRCN_GROUPS) 

Higher or equally prioritized protection groups of the matching supply protection object are treated as restriction. Here, the BAdI “Removal of Restriction Groups” can change the restrictions. It’s possible to ignore any other protection group of the matching supply protection object. With this a matching demand is less restricted and the likelihood of getting a confirmation for a request increases. 

For sure, the reliability of the protection in total is reduced if the restriction is not that strict. 

Illustration: Removal of Restrictions

Remove Restriction Groups Inside Privileged Check Quantity (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN) 

The restriction type “Restriction outside planned protection” is a bit more complex as there are potentially two different checks for the availability. If you are not familiar with the restriction type “Restriction outside planned protection” you should read the related community blog. 
One of the principles is as follows: If the requested quantity is below the remaining protection of the matching time bucket, the restriction is low. For requested quantities which exceed the remaining protection of the matching time bucket the restriction is high. 

Illustration: Removal of Restrictions ”Inside Privileged Check Quantity”

In the illustration, parallel restrictions with the same priority also exist. Equal and higher prioritized protections are considered as restrictions for the check “inside the privileged check quantity”. With the BAdI ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN it is possible to remove these restrictions. 

Remove Restriction Groups Outside Privileged Check Quantity (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_OUT) 

For demands exceeding the remaining protection of the matching time bucket, the restriction might be high, as also lower prioritized protections are considered as restriction. This is a basic principle of the restriction type “Restriction outside planned protection”. However, for this kind of restrictions a BAdI exists to remove protection groups. If there are many vertical protection groups, it might be interesting to not be restricted by all the groups of lower priority, but just by the groups which are one or two levels below. 

Using the BAdIs to remove restrictions is something every customer should think about very carefully.
Although the following setting is possible, it might not always be reasonable. So, it would be wrong to have a demand facing a lower restriction if it is already outside of the own protection compared to the restrictions of the first check within the own protection. 


Illustration: Removal of Restrictions ”Outside Privileged Check Quantity” 

Change of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups 
(ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT) 

With the BAdI “Change of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups” it is possible to change the quantity we also sometimes call the “Inplan-Quantity” or the “privileged Quantity”. This is the quantity which is checked for the first check for the restriction type “Restriction outside planned Protection”. Sometime customers want to have more flexibility here as well. One simple use case is as follows ... 
If there are monthly time buckets the remaining protection might be quite low at the end of the month as the protection is already consumed. If the request matched the next time bucket, the confirmed quantities would be higher again. Therefore, some customers want to consider the protected quantities of the following or previous time bucket as an additional quantity for the first check. In this case they also want to redistribute the consumption afterwards again, so that consumptions exceeding the own planned protections are only stored at a time bucket, if the remaining protection of the surrounding time buckets is already expired.  


Illustration: With the BAdI ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT quantities of additional time buckets are considered as ”Privileged Check Quantity”

There are different options to change the logic of Supply Protection and customer can use the application more flexible. However, every change of the logic in standard has an impact, and the BAdIs should be used very carefully. 

Links 

SAP Help: App Extensibility: Manage Supply Protection (Key User) 
SAP Community: Increasing Reliability with Supply Protection
SAP Community: Restriction by Own Protection in Supply Protection
SAP Community: Restriction outside Planned Protection

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP IBP New Harmonized Planning Area (SAPIBP2)
entry.content:
This blog has been created for the sole purpose of helping customers looking to implement the new Harmonized Planning Area (HPA) in their IBP landscape. It contains all the technical pre-requisites with links, important tips and FAQs to help you kick-start with your HPA adoption journey.

 Harmonized Planning Area: Solution Information

The solution offered with the 2508 release in SAP IBP is the Harmonized Planning Area (HPA) where only one planning area will be used for Mid-long term planning with time-series buckets, and short-mid term planning with orders, using the same data model ​(attributes, master data types, key figures, planning levels, time profile, etc.)​. The new sample planning area will be called I_SAPIBP2 (The “I” denotes use of name spaces in the planning area.) Here, the “harmonized” master data model will be used by all IBP modules, including order-based supply, time-series supply, inventory, S&OP and demand.

Related Links:

  • Webinar Harmonized Planning area 2508-PDF​
  • Webinar Harmonized Planning area 2508-Recording​
  • IBP 2508 What's New Introducing I_SAPIBP2​
  • The data model and supported functionality can be viewed here I_SAPIBP2 Online Help​

SAPIBP2 Technical Pre-requisites:

  • HANA Cloud

Customers that are not on HANA Cloud 2.0 must request a tenant migration prior to starting with SAPIBP2 (HPA)

For details refer to SAP Note 3217536​ IBP: Upgrade to HANA Cloud - Overview for customers and partners​

 

  • Real Time Integration (RTI)

RTI is mandatory for Order-Based Planning (OBP).

For those customers who do not have RTI installed yet, start with the Central RTI note: 3110007 - IBP Real-time Integration: Information/Restrictions. The note contains all the information that you need to start with the implementation including the current restrictions as well as the technical prerequisite within the notes.

Note: Please ensure that the prerequisites mentioned in the note are met!​

To start with the RTI setup we strongly recommend to use :

  1. The setup-check list (link in the note)​
  2. We strongly recommend to use CIAS (Cloud Integration Automation Service) to setup the connection between IBP, the cloud connector and your ECC (link to CIAS in the note). This will reduce the time for the setup significantly, specially for the part with the BTP connector.

To use RTI with your ECC, check SAP note 3106619 - SAP IBP Real-time integration - Notes for installation.

  • It contains for each SAP ERP or SAP S/4 HANA the required service packs or – if not applicable – the notes that must be installed.​
  • PLEASE NOTE: to use the RTI functionality for a certain IBP version you MUST install ALL notes of the previous version as well in the given sequence. After the installation of the service packs or the notes there are additional notes with corrections, bug fixes etc.​
  • Do also check all notes related to the SNOTE tool and install any fixes.​
  • Plan for sufficient time and resources (experienced analyst or developer with ABAP workbench and SNOTE experience).

RTI FAQ with links to webinars: FAQs: SAP IBP Real-Time Integration and Transition from SDI

Further information:​

Usage of CIAS to setup RTI efficiently​:

  • Configuring RTI Connectivity with Cloud Integration Automation Service (CIAS) | SAP Help Portal​
  • Fast track your SAP IBP Real time integration jour... - SAP Community​
  • Extending Efficiency: Automating IBP RTI Connectiv... - SAP Community​

Important note: All the projects that are starting with time series planning and eventually want to get to order based planning, we strongly advise getting started with RTI early so that the integration infrastructure doesn't have to change at a later point in the project.

  • Restrictions 2640432 - Details on Restrictions for SAP IBP Order-Based Planning - SAP for Me ​

Integration Strategy: RTI, CI, CIDS:

  • RTI is the recommended and future-proof integration technology for both order-based and time series planning in HPA, advising early adoption to ensure consistent master data flows and minimize future architectural changes.
  • While CIDS will continue to be supported  existing customers, new development and investment are shifting toward CI. CIDS will be removed from the IBP product bundle in 2026, but current users can continue using it for their existing processes. 
  • Recommended use of CI (Cloud Integration) and the development of custom integration flows (iflows), with the recommendation to leverage existing reusable iflows where possible and supplement with CIDS as needed until future releases provide more comprehensive coverage.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ):

 

S. No

Question

Answered by EAC Team

1

DC (XPC) is not yet HANA Cloud ready.​

Work is being done around this and there will soon be an update.​

2

If a key figure in HPA is using the new UoM conversion - do we need to pass the UoM to the CI-DS for extraction?​

when using the new UoM conversion the planning area must contain the conversion attributes. The new UoM conversion generates automatically the calculations. To CI-DS the calculation view contains in the metadata the attribute I_UOMTOID. This can be set for filtering on a specific UoM​

3

Is CIDS supported with IBP2508? ​

CI is strategic and advisable for long run. Existing customers may continue to use CI-DS. For HPA projects, we advise using RTI as the primary integration mechanism for master data (and orders, stocks, etc), so it is consistent between TSP and OBP.​

4

Do I have to integrate on one hand via CIDS and in parallel via RTI and all the developments we did in the in the back end system to enrich the data. Do I have then to implement everything again?​

In case you want to use through all the processes the same data and you have the corresponding data in your S4 system, the then the recommendation is definitely to use RTI so that you get then the master data synchronized between all applications from one single point. There are extensions available so you can extend RTI up to a certain point.​

5

How do I raise a customer Influence request for IBP?​

With a valid S-User you can raise this here.​

6

How do objects in IBPSAP7F relate to objects in HPA. ​

Will be shared soon.

7

Is this now an RTI periodic job?​

S/4 -> IBP = real time​                                                                                                                                                             IBP ->S/4 = depending on your requirement, it can be real-time or as batch job (system settings)​

8

Which notes do I have to implement?​

3106619 - SAP IBP Real-time integration - Notes for installation - SAP for Me​. Read & implement it from top down

9

RTI outbound integration – is it possible to differentiate STRs? eg: deployment STRs vs DRP STR ​

Yes, PReq and STR can be differentiated when selecting, but not between normal STR and Deployment STR​

10

Recommendation of implementing Supply and Response and IO in one planning area with HPA?​

The recommendation is context specific, so "it depends". There are three scenarios. (1) Most customers group IO with supply due to technical alignment on network master data. But some IBP customers view IO as part of the demand consensus business process (combining forecasting and risk/safety management), so they either (2) group IO with demand or (3) keep it in a separate PA.​

11

Do existing customer have to pay additionally for CI-DS license if they want to continue?​

No change for existing customers. New customers that get their system beyond Q1/2026 will not receive a CIDS Org as a bundle with IBP but must license CI additionally.​

12

Is SAP CI different from BTP-Integration Suite (Cloud Platform Integration) ? or is it the new name for the same tool?​ If it is the same, are there many pre-delivered IBP flows which can be configured in the 'design' tab of the Integration Suite environment? ​

SAP BTP Integration Suite is the umbrella offering, and CI is one of its core services. CI is part of the BTP integration suite, and we do have iFlows. But at the moment, the pre-delivered iFlows is pretty limited.​ We are working on more flows.​

13

Is 'segmentation' in S/4 mandatory to use CBP in IBP or is 'classification' in S/4 sufficient? ​

Officially released is the segmentation only.​ For other classes, you may need to implement some BADI. But please note that CBP is not in the MVP (Minimum Viable Product) for HPA.​​ IBP CBP and order-based shelf life planning is planned for inclusion in I_SAPIBP2 in the February release 2602. (Depending of course on successful QA.)​

14

if there is any functionality planned in the roadmap that would allow for selective export of specific planning area objects—such as key figures, planning levels —to a higher system in the landscape, rather than exporting the entire planning area configuration​

Nothing on the roadmap as such.​

15

Is there an ability to trigger CI jobs directly from IBP or can they only be triggered/scheduled directly in CI?​

As of today, only via CI directly. ​But that is a roadmap item and currently planned for early next year (but legal disclaimer, changes can come at any point in time)​

16

Planned Independent Requirements (Forecast) please - is it going to be part of the CFM1 selection screen as other transactional data types? This would help to enable proper FC consumption and its synchronization between S4 and OBP.​

No, forecast is not coming over via RTI​

17

CBP is not part of EAC program?​

For CBP restrictions, please check as well on ​

2640432 - Details on Restrictions for SAP IBP Order-Based Planning - SAP for Me --> search for "Characteristic Based Planning (CBP)"

and ​3422877 - Prerequisites and Restriction with Characteristic Based Planning (CBP) in response and su…​
​
 especially​
 "In the backend: ​

1)You have implemented all notes relevant for CBP, see (SAP Note 3435209 - Characteristic Based Planning (CBP) and E2E integration support with backend processes)​

2)You either use ​
a)segmentation in S/4HANA​
b)batch classification for stock only and/or implement RTI BAdI on backend side (from ERP EHP4 or S/4HANA)​
 "​

But you can still proceed, because you can add CBP functionality later, does not need to be used from the very beginning

18

What are the efforts/estimates to move from CIDS to CI?​

there is no automatic tool for migration from CI-DS to CI. Therefore you would need to start over. The target is that we replace most of the data flow with RTI.​ And you dont need to replace a CI-DS flow for e.g. Sales History, you can just copy and re-map it to the new planning area. As existing customer, you still have the license for CI-DS​. If you WANT to create new CI flows, you can still use the same source in S/4 which potentially uses the addon. So for an experienced person it should take a couple of hours for a flow.​

19

We are planning to use RTI as much as possible but we have a few additional attributes at Product and Location Product master data level, currently these attributes are maintained in a Custom table, if we integrate these with RTI BADI then how can trigger a change pointer when an attribute value is updated in the Custom table ​

Support document link on the same will be shared soon.

20

Given that we will focus only on S&OP processes for the moment, and that their S/4HANA system (2023 FPS1) will only be upgraded to a higher release in 2026, is it technically feasible and supported to implement RTI inbound integration in the meantime by applying only the HPA-relevant notes below, without upgrading to the latest FPS (staying on S/4 2023 FPS1) or applying all other required SAP Notes manually ?​

​Need to apply all the notes that are listed in the central sub notes. So you start basically at your current release and you need to upgrade at least to the point where HPA was introduced, simply applying the nodes that are HPA relevant.​ (https://me.sap.com/notes/3106619/E​)

21

What is your suggestion either to go with CI or CIDS, along with RTI between S4 and IBP, Considering we already have CIDS between IBP and BW/BI. And which integration is preferable between Datasphere and IBP​

Datasphere is a cloud solution, and there you should go with CI.​

22

[Data models] ​

Will the OKF always remain on that granularity of "Sales Order new", "Sales order released" , "Sales order confirmed" etc. - for Supply planning for example it is sufficient to have the "Sales orders (all open)" as an aggregate if you run weekly buckets for example.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 2 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Data, AI, and Agents are Changing Supply Chain Planning

In the discussion about the future of supply chain management, one area is increasingly at the center: planning. Supply chain planning not only affects operational efficiency, but directly influences a company’s service quality, fixed capital and responsiveness. Our joint study from SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University clearly shows that companies that are already planning proactively today can avoid bottlenecks, optimize costs, and exploit potential in a targeted manner.

Supply chain planning is the central lever for anticipating problems before they arise. Companies that anticipate bottlenecks and proactively manage capacity, inventory and resources avoid hectic “fire fighting” in day-to-day operations. Planning thus acts as an early warning system that not only enables stable service, but also more efficient use of resources and proactive action. Effective planning also requires seamless integration and evaluation of a variety of internal and external data sources – from granular sales data to basic economic data, to production, procurement, and distribution plans. Different planning levels and horizons need to be connected, and this is where there are huge opportunities for artificial intelligence that can process data volumes, identify patterns, and improve predictions. Advanced planning processes will become a matter of course over the next ten years. If you do not achieve at least a modern, integrated planning level by 2035, you risk not only a competitive disadvantage, but also the loss of operational control capability.

Our survey of supply chain decision-makers (see figure) provides a clear picture of the future. Many expect planning to be much simpler and more intuitive in 2035 than today. More than half expect generative AI and GPT models to have a significant impact on planning processes, and much of it sees data quality as a critical factor in planning decisions. In addition, many expect the breakthrough of new AI-powered forecasting tools that incorporate additional data sources and significantly improve demand planning. Around a quarter expect advanced risk analysis to provide the ability to proactively detect and mitigate disruptions.

However, the status quo shows how big the gap between aspirations and reality is. Only a small number of companies rated their planning as mature in our survey. Similarly, few are actively experimenting with GenAI or GPT applications in the planning environment. Only a minority has very accurate planning data harmonized from different sources. Highly automated demand planning with minimal human intervention is the exception, as are planning systems that provide clear recommendations for action in the event of disruptions. This discrepancy shows that the path to truly modern, intelligent planning is still long and requires targeted investment, clear priorities and structured action.

In order to close this gap, different approaches must be pursued. Companies where planning is a strategic core process or requires very individual processes can realize enormous potential with agent-based AI. With the advent of new agency tools, most repetitive, error-prone work is automated, allowing planners to focus on value-added analytics and decisions. Companies with standardized processes and a low strategic relevance of planning will be able to procure their planning function more as a service in the future. Technology and platform models could enable true end-to-end planning across company boundaries for the first time. Simulations and digital twins will also play a growing role. Although these often fail today due to complexity, modeling effort, and scalability, AI-powered modeling agents could significantly accelerate and improve the accuracy of simulation creation and updates in the future, making their use more practical in larger networks.

Regardless of the individual target image, there are measures that every company should tackle immediately (“no-regret moves”). This includes building robust data governance and harmonizing master data as the foundation for any data-driven planning. Unfortunately, the principle of “garbage in, garbage out” also applies with AI: without high-quality data, even the best AI system cannot deliver meaningful value. A consistent, company-wide IBP system enabling a S&OP process provides the basis for a common planning goal. Initial pilot projects with agent-based sales forecasting help gather experience with AI-powered planning approaches. Finally, it is important to actively link existing planning platforms, such as SAP IBP, with AI services to unlock integration potential early on.

Supply chain planning is now more important than ever and will become a key differentiator between successful companies and those left behind by 2035. The technologies to make planning smarter, faster, and more resilient already exist – but they must be combined with clear goals, a resilient data foundation, and organizational readiness for change. Those who lay the foundations today will not only be able to plan faster and more precisely tomorrow but can also act strategically before others can even react.

Figure: Results of an online survey of 119 SC managers with people responsibility, conducted on 01/2025 as part of a joint SAP KLU study

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future”.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 3 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: Is Artificial Intelligence Determining Future Purchasing?

The third part of the joint study by SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University on the supply chain of the future deals with purchasing. We do not assume the future of purchasing looks the same for all companies. Rather, key trends and key technologies play a big role. Their impact varies greatly depending on the industry and business model.

The shaping trends for purchasing (as well as for the other parts of the supply chain) include the global economic situation and geopolitical tensions, the growing importance of sustainability, the scarcity of raw materials, and the changes for the people involved. These issues are not new, but they will play a major role in the coming years and will sometimes become even bigger. 

Key technologies are in the focus, e.g. integrated transactional purchasing applications with new semantic data models, AI agents, AI-based data analyses, and insights from the evaluation of information from business networks. Artificial intelligence is not the only driving technology but will become increasingly relevant in the coming years. No process in modern purchasing organizations will remain unaffected by its influence. Against this background, purchasing organizations have to work out which trends and technologies are particularly important for their company to plan the path to a successful future.

The study conducted an online survey of 174 supply chain managers with people responsibility (April 2025). There was a clear discrepancy between ambitious visions for the future and the sad reality. On the one hand, 28% of respondents expected purchasing managers to play an important role in shaping corporate strategy and security of supply in 2035, while 31% expected buying organizations to achieve significantly better AI-driven outcomes with high quality data. On the other hand, only 12% say that procurement in their organization is now fully integrated into C-level decision-making, and only 3% think AI-powered purchasing analytics are great today.

How should this discrepancy be dealt with? And how to deal with the uncertainty of every look into the future? The clear recommendation for all purchasing organizations is to do their homework first, to take decisions and to perform a couple of no-regret moves. It is clear that only purchasing organizations following these five important points are optimally positioned for the coming years.

Firstly, clearly defined strategies and responsible people are in place for the most important categories and sub-categories. These category strategies must be kept up to date in suitable applications instead of gathering dust in presentations stored on shared drives. The strategies will be the trigger for activities, and the focal point for monitoring the progress of the activities.

Secondly, the operating model of the purchasing organization must be optimized by shifting personnel capacities from administrative activities to value-adding tasks. The goal is to work with a small but highly skilled workforce.

Third, clearly defined and standardized processes are required that exist in Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN) notation and are mapped in a process management solution, not a drawing tool. On this basis, simulations and comparisons of as-is and to-be can be carried out. Also, the processes can be linked to business requirements, test cases, application documentation, driving AI based automation in these related activities.

Fourth, modern purchasing applications should be used to support end-to-end processes, without media breaks and with a steadily growing degree of automation. An end-to-end flow of data and information is essential. Specifications and prices belong into the apps themselves, not in file attachments. These pieces of information are critical parts of the data that drives AI. Similarly, the apps must be integrated so data is not transferred manually or via bots.

Fifth, all relevant data from various procurement apps and third-party data must be available for analysis. The key is that this data is available on an appropriate platform and mapped to a semantic model. This is the only way to get an overview of the entire purchasing process, to derive in-depth insights and to drive more AI use cases.

The last point is of particular importance. Only if data on purchasing processes is available in structured form, across all purchasing processes, in good quality, will the purchasing organization have a solid basis for using AI functionalities of any kind, especially AI-driven analytics and AI agents, which can take on complex tasks on their own.

AI agents sound a bit like science fiction for many persons in the procurement space – that is why the figure below outlines an agentic AI scenario in strategic procurement. The CPO sets a task for a procurement orchestration agent which in turn sets tasks for other, more specialized procurement agents (e.g. spend analysis, sourcing activities, contract creation) to achieve an overall goal, the optimization of a specific sub-category.

Similarly, all other parties involved in the purchasing processes can be supported. Requestors can interact with an operational purchasing agents to quickly and clearly describe their needs. That operational purchasing agent reaches out to other agents leveraging existing contracts or catalogs, adhering to all purchasing guidelines, and covering topics such as account assignment, tax determination, and transportation costs. With the help of their own agents, suppliers will find it easy to participate in complex tenders, bid in Dutch or Japanese auctions, negotiate and sign contracts, and provide price lists and catalogs in specific formats to the purchasing organization. Since suppliers will use their own AI agents, there will be an increasing frequency of interaction between multiple agents.

In summary, it can be said that those purchasing organizations will be optimally positioned for the future, who correctly classify the relevance of future trends and technologies to their own business, and who conclude the five no-regret moves mentioned above.

Figure: AI agents implement a complex task in purchasing

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future”.

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM

  • /SCWM/LM_ELS

  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING

2. Activate Labor Management

14. Create a Processor

T.Code: /N/SCMB/PRR1
